Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Specific chemical binding (Al-O-P coordination bonds) with phospholipid layer for efficient enrichment.

Other Information.Test Conditions: Incubation at 4 °C for 30 min for enrichment; pH 6 for dissociation
Other Information.Additional Info: High affinity for negatively charged BEVs. Controlled capture and release via pH adjustment.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Less efficient chemical binding due to lower density of phosphate groups on their surface, leading to reduced capture compared to BEVs.

Other Information.Additional Info: Present as contaminants, but are selectively enriched less efficiently than BEVs by AlNS.

Sieving Mechanism: Selective enrichment/separation based on specific surface chemical interactions (Al-O-P bonding) with phospholipid layers, differentiating from entities with lower phosphate group density.

Experimental Validation.Method: TEM, DLS, ζ-potential, FT-IR, XPS, flow cytometry, Western Blot, Bradford protein assay, RiboGreen RNA quantitative detection, SPV method for phospholipid quantification, single-layer agar plate method, SDS-PAGE protein gel, methodological comparison with SEC.
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: 26-fold higher protein content (up to 3.67 μg) than traditional method (0.139 μg); ~8-fold higher RNA content; significantly elevated phospholipid levels; BEV enrichment up to 40% of total BEVs; absence of phage contamination; preserved bamA and ompA expression levels; significant retention of endotoxin content.

Other Information.Additional Info: Al-based metal-organic nanoslice (AlNS); Two-dimensional irregular shapes; Hydrodynamic diameter ~300 nm; Positive charge; Good crystallinity; Able to respond to environmental changes for controlled capture/release of BEVs; Designed for enrichment of biological external vesicles, not traditional molecular sieving of small molecules.
